questions.text: Sepsis is a common and deadly disease. More than two millennia ago, Hippocrates wrote that sepsis was characterized by rotting flesh and festering wounds. Several centuries later, Galen described sepsis as a laudable event required for wound healing. According to germ theory, sepsis was recast as a systemic infection referred to as “blood poisoning” and was thought to be due to pathogen invasion and spread in the bloodstream of the host. Since then, the explanation of sepsis has changed a lot, as has the pathogenesis. Which is not true about pathogenesis of sepsis?

options.label: A
options.text: More recently, it has become apparent that sepsis is a result of an excessive inflammatory host response

options.label: B
options.text: The specific response of each patient depends on the pathogen (load and virulence) and the host (genetic composition and comorbidity), with different responses at local and systemic levels

options.label: C
options.text: Proinflammatory reactions (directed at eliminating pathogens) are responsible for “collateral” tissue damage in sepsis, whereas antiinflammatory responses are implicated in the enhanced susceptibility to secondary infections that occur later in the course

options.label: D
options.text: The host’s ability to resist as well as tolerate both direct and immunopathologic damage will determine whether an uncomplicated infection becomes sepsis

questions.correct_answer: A. More recently, it has become apparent that sepsis is a result of an excessive inflammatory host response
questions.explanation:
Solution:

More recently, it has become apparent that sepsis is a result of an excessive inflammatory host response. Sepsis: d ysregulated host response to infection that leads to acute organ dysfunction. Sepsis occurs when the local proinflammatory immune processes become exaggerated, resulting in a generalised immune response. Aberrant inflammatory response, cellular alterations, endothelial dysfunction, and circulatory abnormalities predispose to organ dysfunction. The host response evolves over time with the patient’s clinical course. These mechanisms can be characterized as an interplay between two “fitness costs.” Direct damage to organs by the pathogen Damage to organs stemming from the host’s immune response Option A: For many years, the clinical features of sepsis were considered the result of an excessive inflammatory host response (SIRS), but recent views have changed that. Hence this is not the correct statement.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B : This is true. The specific response of each patient depends on the pathogen ( load and virulence ) and the host ( genetic composition and comorbidity ), with different responses at local and systemic levels. Option C: This is true. Pro-inflammatory reactions ( directed at eliminating pathogens) are responsible for “collateral” tissue damage in sepsis, whereas anti-inflammatory responses are implicated in the enhanced susceptibility to secondary infections. Option D : This is true. The host’s ability to resist as well as tolerate both direct and immunopathologic damage will determine whether uncomplicated infection becomes sepsis.

questions.text: Sepsis is considered as a life threatening organ dysfunction caused by dysregulated host response to infection. One common cause of death in sepsis is DIC, which is an abnormality of coagulation. What could be the possible positive impact of these abnormalities of coagulation?

options.label: A
options.text: Isolate invading microorganisms and/or to prevent the spread of infection and inflammation to other tissues and organs

options.label: B
options.text: To combat in advance possible internal hemorrhages, which can develop because of sepsis

options.label: C
options.text: To block blood supply to areas of the brain that are the center of generation of the dysregulated host response

questions.correct_answer: A. Isolate invading microorganisms and/or to prevent the spread of infection and inflammation to other tissues and organs
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Isolate invading microorganisms and/or to prevent the spread of infection and inflammation to other tissues and organs. Sepsis occurs when the local proinflammatory immune processes become exaggerated, resulting in a generalized immune response. Sepsis is commonly associated with coagulation disorders and frequently leads to DIC (Disseminated intravascular coagulation). Abnormalities in coagulation are thought to isolate invading microorganisms and/or to prevent the spread of infection and inflammation to other tissues and organs ( Option A is correct )

questions.text: A 29-year-old laborer was admitted with a short history of headache, abdominal pain and vomiting. He had previously been well, and had been at work on the morning of admission. A splenectomy had been performed 10 years previously for traumatic splenic rupture. On admission he was flushed, pyrexial (38.5°C) and slightly dehydrated, with a pulse of 105/min and BP of 140/90 mmHg. Investigations included Hb 14-0 g/dl, WCC 54 x 109/1, plasma urea 6-4 mmol/l and normal plasma electrolytes. After 2 days of admission, there were scattered coarse crackles throughout both lungs. He was hyperventilating but hypoxic with warm and bounding skin and an arterial Po2 of 7.2 kPa (54.0 mmHg) and Pco2 of 36 kPa (27 mmHg). His BP fell to 70/40 mmHg, but responded to norepinephrine and steroids. Chest X ray is consistent with pictures of ARDS. Blood cultures will yield a heavy growth of?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Streptococcus The clinical scenario of a post splenectomy patient presenting with symptoms and signs suggestive of focus of infection with low BP indicating sepsis with ARDS and requiring vasopressor support → Septic shock Overwhelming Post splenectomy infection (OPSI) The most serious consequence of splenectomy is increased susceptibility to bacterial infections, particularly those with capsules Streptococcus pneumonia – Most common ( Option B is the answer) Haemophilus influenzae Neisseria meningitidis Some gram- negative enteric organisms. Patients aged < 20 years are particularly susceptible to overwhelming sepsis with S. pneumonia. The susceptibility to bacterial infections relates to the Inability to remove opsonized bacteria from the bloodstream Defect in making antibodies to T-cell–independent antigens such as the polysaccharide components of bacterial capsules. About 15% of the infections are polymicrobial, and lung, skin and blood are the most common sites

Highyeild:

Splenectomy is performed for Symptom control in patients with massive splenomegaly, Disease control in patients with traumatic splenic rupture Correction of cytopenias in patients with hypersplenism Immune-mediated destruction of one or more cellular blood elements Only contraindication to splenectomy is the presence of marrow failure (Enlarged spleen is the only source of hematopoietic tissue)

Pneumococcal vaccine should be administered to all patients 2 weeks before elective splenectomy. The case-fatality rate for pneumococcal sepsis in splenectomized patients is 50–80%.

questions.text: A series of pathogenic events responsible for sepsis post burn injury. Following severe burn injury, damaged tissues lead to the release of endogenous DAMPs (such as double-stranded RNA and mitochondrial DNA) and exogenous PAMPs (such as lipopolysaccharides and peptidoglycans). Subsequently, PAMPs can result in vascular leak and hypovolemic shock, immune and inflammatory responses and metabolic changes. Vascular leak causes tissue edema, organ hypoperfusion and increasing risk of bacterial infection. Meanwhile, the excessive inflammatory response leads to immunosuppression by inhibition of the innate and adaptive immune systems. Which of the following will be the most common organism in blood culture in such a patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa Protection against infection of the epidermis depends on the mechanical barrier afforded by the stratum corneum , since the epidermis itself is devoid of blood vessels. Disruption of this layer by burns allows the penetration of bacteria in to the deeper structures . Burn injuries can also influence other elements of both the innate immune system (including immune cells and complement) and the adaptive immune system, which disrupts coordination of the immune response. The m ost common organism associated with burns is Pseudomonas aeruginosa that can lead to septic shock . Burn eschar (avascular necrotic tissue) caused by deep partial-thickness and full-thickness burns provides a protein-rich niche for bacterial colonization and proliferation. In addition, burn eschar may also increase the risk of infection by inhibiting early healing via basic fibroblast growth factor-induced endothelial cell proliferation and sprouting. However, eschar factors can inhibit hypertrophic scar formation in full- thickness burn wounds by preventing excessive granulation tissue formation.

Highyeild:

Other organisms - Aeromonas hydrophila and gram-negative Ecthyma gangrenosum Most common among patients with extensive burns. Hemorrhagic vesicles surrounded by a rim of erythema with central necrosis and ulceration

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A - streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of sepsis in post splenectomy cases . Option C-staph aureus is present on skin, but in burn skin is lost and so, does staph. Also staph generally doesn't involve sepsis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man who runs a yard service cuts his thumb while attaching an accessory to one of his mowers. The next morning, his thumb is sore and the skin surrounding the cut is red. The man has thirty very impatient customers scheduled for lawn mowing that day so he heads out early and works until early evening. By the time he gets back home, the thumb is swollen and throbbing, and yellowish-white pus is oozing out of the injured area. He also notices two red streaks going up the inside of his forearm. Just as he begins to think about getting some medical attention for his thumb, the man experiences a shaking chill and becomes queasy. His wife then drives him to the ER at the nearest hospital, which takes about 35 minutes because of heavy traffic. Upon their arrival at the ER, the man's temperature has reached 39.7ºC. He is flushed and ill-appearing, with a pulse of 125 and a blood pressure of 100/60 mm Hg. (His normal BP is 145/85 mm Hg.) There are no other remarkable findings on physical examination. What is your preliminary diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

SIRS/Sepsis The clinical scenario of injury, followed by symptoms and signs of infection (e., fever, tachypnoea, and tachycardia), suggest systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS ) SIRS is characterized by the presence of two or more of the following: Fever (> 38ºC) or hypothermia (< 36ºC); Tachypnoea (RR > 24/min); PaCO2 < 32 mm Hg Tachycardia (PR > 90/min) TLC: Leukocytosis (> 12,000/(microliter), leukopenia (< 4,000/microliter), or >10% bands SIRS can have an infectious or non-infectious a In this case, there are obvious signs of microbial infection (pus oozing from a recent skin wound, fever), so a diagnosis of sepsis (i.e., SIRS with a proven or suspected microbial aetiology) is justified. Sepsis is SIRS with a documented infection. (SEPSIS 1,2) Suspected (or documented) infection and an acute increase in ≥2 sepsis-related organ failure assessment (SOFA) points. (SEPSIS - 3) The patient has obvious impending risk of hypotension in addition to the standard SIRS/sepsis symptoms, and appears to be at risk of septic shock (defined as sepsis plus hypotension or one or more signs of organ dysfunction)

Highyeild:

Most common cause of distributive shock is sepsis Norepinephrine is the first choice vasopressor in septic shock Vasopressin has a role as a second agent for hypotension in septic shock

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B - Cardiogenic shock - No history suggestive of primary involvement of heart. Option C - Pulmonary embolism – No hypotension/ chest pain Option D - Exposure induced hypothermia – No evidence of Hypothermia.

questions.text: The unit head of medicine was attending a case presentation of a patient of suspected sepsis. While discussing various advancement in definition and criterias of sepsis, he asked about the latest criteria for the diagnosis of sepsis. One of his pg students named the latest guidelines of SEPSIS - 3. Which of the following is the latest criteria for the diagnosis of sepsis according to SEPSIS - 3.

options.label: A
options.text: Suspected (or documented) infection plus ≥2 systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) criteria

options.label: B
options.text: Suspected (or documented) infection plus persistent arterial hypotension (systolic arterial pressure, <90 mmHg; mean arterial pressure, <60 mmHg; or change in systolic by >40 mmHg from baseline

options.label: C
options.text: Suspected (or documented) infection and an acute increase in ≥2 sepsis-related organ failure assessment (SOFA) points

options.label: D
options.text: Suspected (or documented) infection plus vasopressor therapy needed to maintain mean arterial pressure at ≥65 mmHg and serum lactate >2.0 mmol/L despite adequate fluid resuscitation

questions.correct_answer: C. Suspected (or documented) infection and an acute increase in ≥2 sepsis-related organ failure assessment (SOFA) points
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Suspected (or documented) infection and an acute increase in ≥2 sepsis-related organ failure assessment (SOFA) points. The latest “ Sepsis-3 ” clinical criteria for sepsis include A suspected infection Acute organ dysfunction, defined as an increase by two or more points from baseline (if known) on the sequential (or sepsis-related) organ failure assessment (SOFA) score Septic shock Sepsis plus the need for vasopressor therapy to alleviate mean arterial pressure to ≥ 65 mmHg with a serum lactate concentration >2.0 mmol/L despite adequate fluid resuscitation CONDITION DEFINITION COMMON CLINICAL FEATURES CRITERIA IN 1991/2003 ("SEPSIS-1/SEPSIS-2") CRITERIA IN 2016 ("SEPSIS-3") Sepsis A life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection Include signs of infection, with organ dysfunction, plus altered mentation; tachypnea; hypotension: hepatic, renal, or hematologic dysfunction Suspected (or documented) infection plus ≥2 systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) criteria Suspected (or documented) infection and an acute increase in ≥2 sepsis related organ failure assessment (SOFA) points Septic shock A subset of sepsis in which underlying circulatory and cellular/metabolic abnormalities lead to substantially increased mortality risk Signs of infection, plus altered mentation, oliguria,cool peripheries, hyperlactatemia Suspected (or documented) infection plus persistent arterial hypotension (systolic arterial pressure, <90 mmHg mean arterial pressure, <60 mmHg; or change in systolic by >40 mmHg from baseline Suspected (or documented) infection plus vasopressor therapy needed to maintain mean arterial pressure at ≥65 mmHg and serum lactate >2.0 mmol/L despite adequate fluid resuscitation

questions.text: Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) is a systemic Q. manifestation of sepsis, although the syndrome may also be caused by multiple trauma, burns or pancreatitis without infection. Serious infection, such as secondary peritonitis, may lead to SIRS through the release of lipopolysaccharide endotoxin from the walls of dying Gram-negative bacilli (mainly Escherichia coli) or other bacteria or fungi. This and other toxins stimulate the release of cytokines from macrophages Septic manifestations and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) in SIRS are mediated by the release of which pro-inflammatory cytokines?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IL - 1, TNF-alpha Pro-inflammatory reactions (directed at eliminating pathogens) are responsible for “collateral” tissue damage in sepsis. Septic manifestations and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) in SIRS are mediated by the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as interleukin-1 (IL-1) and tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNFα) . Major anti-inflammatory Cytokine. cytokines include interleukin (IL)-1 receptor antagonist, IL-4, IL-6, IL-10, IL-11, and IL-13. Transforming growth factor beta (TGF-β) is a multifunctional cytokine belonging to the transforming growth factor superfamily. It is most commonly considered an anti-inflammatory The pro-inflammatory cytokines promote neutrophil adhesion to endothelial surfaces adjacent to the source of infection and cause them to migrate through the blood vessel wall by chemotaxis. A respiratory burst occurs within such activated neutrophils, releasing lysosomal enzymes, oxidants, and free radicals, which are involved in killing the invading bacteria but which may also damage adjacent cells .

The findings of examination are Respiratory rate - 25 Pulse rate - 118 SBP - 90 Glasgow Coma Score(GCS) = 10 What will be the value of qSOFA for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

3 Sepsis is defined as life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection. The SOFA (Sequential organ failure assessment) score is a 24-point measure of organ dysfunction Quick SOFA (qSOFA) is used to identify patients at high risk of sepsis outside the ICU. The qSOFA score ranges from 0 to 3 points , with 1 point each for Systolic hypotension (≤ 100 mmHg) Tachypnea (≥ 22 breaths/min) Altered mentation In the above scenario Respiratory rate – 25 ( is > 22 → 1 point) SBP – 90 mm Hg ( is < 100 → 1 point) Glasgow Coma Score(GCS) = 10 (Altered mentation → 1 point ) So total = 3 points (q SOFA )

qSOFA in this question = respiratory rate + SBP + altered mental status One point each. So correct answer will be 3. Pulse rate is not included in calculation of qSOFA. qSOFA score calculatotion will help you identify high mortality risk in a patient with an infection (outside the ICU - Intensive Care Unit) using qSOFA criteria system. qSOFA Score Calculator GCS <15 pts Respiratory Rate (RR > 22 breaths per min Systolic Blood Pressure (SBP) ≤ 100 mmHg qSOFA score 3 pts

questions.text: The specific clinical manifestations of sepsis are quite variable, depending on the initial site of infection, the offending pathogen, the pattern of acute organ dysfunction, the underlying health of the patient, and the delay before initiation of treatment. The signs of both infection and organ dysfunction may be subtle. Which of the following organ systems is most commonly affected in sepsis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cardiorespiratory system The two most commonly affected organ systems in sepsis are the respiratory and cardiovascular systems. Cardiovascular compromise typically presents as hypotension. Respiratory compromise classically manifests as ARDS Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)Defined as hypoxemia and bilateral infiltrates of non-cardiac origin that arise within 7 days of the suspected infection.

Highyeild:

As per Berlin criteria ARDS can be classified as Mild (Pao2 /Fio2 , 201–300 mmHg) Moderate (101–200 mmHg) Severe (≤ 100 mmHg).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B – Renal manifestation as Acute kidney injury ( AKI ) is documented in >50% of septic patients presenting as oliguria, azotemia and rising serum creatinine levels. Option D – GI involvement including ileus occurs late Cardiorespiratory Failure Two of the most commonly affected organ systems in sepsis are the respiratory and cardiovascular systems. Respiratory compromise classically manifests as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), defined as hypoxemia and bilateral infiltrates of non- cardiac origin that arise within 7 days of the suspected infection. ARDS can be classified by Berlin criteria as mild (PaO./FO, 201-300 mmHg), moderate (101-200 mmHg), or severe (s100 mmHg). A common com- peting diagnosis is hydrostatic edema secondary to cardiac failure or volume overload. Although traditionally identified by elevated pulmo- nary capillary wedge measurements from a pulmonary artery catheter (>18 mmHg), cardiac failure can be objectively evaluated on the basis of clinical judgment or focused echocardiography. Cardiovascular compromise typically presents as hypotension. The cause can be frank hypovolemia, maldistribution of blood flow and intravascular volume due to diffuse capillary leakage, reduced sys- temic vascular resistance, or depressed myocardial function. After ade- quate volume expansion, hypotension frequently persists, requiring the use of vasopressors. In early shock, when volume status is reduced, systemic vascular resistance may be quite high with low cardiac out- put after volume repletion, however, this picture may rapidly change to low systemic vascular resistance and high cardiac output. Cardiovascular compromise typically presents as hypotension. The cause can be frank hypovolemia, maldistribution of blood flow and intravascular volume due to diffuse capillary leakage, reduced systemic vascular resistance, or depressed myocardial function. Option B -Acute kidney injury (AKI) is documented in >50% of septic patients, increasing the risk of in-hospital death by six- to eightfold. AKI manifests as oliguria, azotemia, and rising serum creatinine levels and frequently requires dialysis. Option D - Many other abnormalities occur in sepsis, including ileus, elevated aminotransferase levels, altered glycemic control, thrombocytopenia and disseminated intravascular coagulation, adrenal dysfunction, and sick euthyroid syndrome.
